results.title: The Lost time capsule
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Bennett, Heather Ogilvie, Australian Bicentennial Authority and Look At It My Way Films
results.brief_description: In the year 2088 a group of children discover a time capsule from the Bicentenary year. When opened it shows a short, musical, promotional film with the theme “Living together always”, highlighting the multicultural nature of Australian society, the outdoor life, brief film excerpts from Australia’s modern history, culminating in the creation of a mural by schoolchildren.

results.title: Settle down country
results.creator_credit: David Batty, Jim Buckell, Pam Nathan, CAAC, CAAMA, NAIHO and Western Deserts Oustations Council
results.brief_description: Documents the return of the Pintubi people to their own lands after many years on Government run settlements. Extensive use of archival footage offers an added historical perspective to this account of the efforts of these people to retain their cultural heritage. Based on the book of the same name by Dick Leichleitner Japanangka and Pam Nathan.

results.title: Aboriginal bark painting
results.creator_credit: Latrobe University. School of Education. Media Centre
results.brief_description: Made in partnership with the Barinaga Aboriginal Co-operative at Maningrida, Northern Territory. Provides an informative look at the bark paintings of Arnhem Land, placing the art work firmly in the context of Aboriginal belief systems and using traditional techniques. A useful complement to “The art and craft of Maningrida”. Narrated by Robin Cuming.

results.title: Whitewashed
results.creator_credit: Sue Ross and New South Wales Institute of Technology
results.brief_description: Examines the removal of Aboriginal children from their families and their placement in foster homes with white parents, the effect upon the children and the continuation of the practice in NSW today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sue Ross and New South Wales Institute of Technology

results.title: Warriors
results.creator_credit: Richard Guthrie, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Rainbow serpent”.
Bob Maza and Eric Willmot, author of an unpublished novel on the exploits of Pemulwuy, who led resistance to the British colonisation of Australia, discuss the role that Pemulwuy and other Aboriginal warriors played in the early years of the British colony of Australia. Their guerrilla and confrontational tactics are contrasted with those of Bennelong, who sought some form of reconciliation. The program includes dramatised enactments of some of these events.

results.title: Sacred sites
results.creator_credit: Richard Guthrie, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Rainbow serpent”.
Bob Maza narrates this exploration of Australian First Nations people’s relationship to sacred sites. Several sites are visited with their guardians who explain the importance of maintaining the sites and protecting them from the tourist, mining and agricultural industries. Sites visited include, Merella Cave, W.A., Uluru, Alice Springs, Guru Guru Cave, W.A. and Milbrodale, N.S.W. There are also extensive interviews with Charles Perkins.

results.title: Survivors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Rainbow serpent”.
This program, narrated by playwright and actor, Bob Maza, concentrates on the attempts by the 4000 strong Tasmanian First Nations community to reveal that Truganini was not “the last of the Tasmanians”, and in doing so, to re-establish their pride and identity in contemporary Tasmanian society. These attempts include the production of the first play by and about Tasmanian First Nations peoples- “We are the Survivors”, by Jim Everett, and the campaign by activist and barrister, Michael Mansell, to reclaim the remains of Tasmanian First Nations people stored in the Anatomy Department of the University of Edinburgh.

results.title: Chocolates, giants and peaches. Parts 1, 2 and 3
results.creator_credit: Lily Steiner, Statewide School Support and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: Roald Dahl, recorded live at the Dallas Brooks Hall in Melbourne, talks about his writing and reads aloud from his own books, including Revolting Rhymes”, “BFG”, “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory”, “Matilda and “Dirty Beasts”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lily Steiner, Statewide School Support and Victoria. Ministry of Education

results.title: Women: three views
results.creator_credit: Richard Guthrie, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Rainbow serpent”.
Interviews with three First Nations women who have chosen to be activists in the struggle for their peoples’ rights. Mum Shirl has been an activist since the late sixties, including initiating the famous “Tent Embassy” in the early seventies. Since then she has become disillusioned with political processes in Australia and now chooses to work directly with First Nations people in prisons. Marcia Langton works for the Central Lands Council in Alice Springs and she talks passionately on behalf of First Nations peoples’ struggles for land rights and dignity. Maryanne Bin-Sallik works within government departments using established political means to argue for the rights of First Nations peoples. Though choosing very different ways to express their activism, we see that all three women are united in their commitment to work towards an autonomous and central role for First Nations peoples in Australian politics and culture.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Guthrie, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and SBS-TV

results.title: Albert Tucker
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Painters, the sculptors: archival art series”.
Albert Tucker describes his early years as a young artist in the Depression and his adolescent awakening to the styles of the great Australian and European painters including Streeton, Cezanne, Van Gogh and Gauguin. He talks of time spent with contemporaries such as John and Sunday Reed, George Bell, Adrian Lawlor and Yosl Bergner, and his own involvement in many of the major artistic events in Australia. Filmed in St. Kilda, 24-28 September, 1986.
